TLDR Review: A sweet short treat, with a well-crafted world, and a satisfying conclusion. But god I did not enjoy the ‚Äú2010s internet‚Äù lingo in the dialogue writing.

In-depth review:

Pros:
- It was touted as a "cozy open world", and in many ways, I prefer it to a more expansive one. There's a surprising amount of activities stacked into a small space: from fishing, digging, watering flowers, boating, climbing, to treasure hunting (of which I found a grand total of zero treasures). There's no wasted space and that's great.

- Mark Sparling's music is fantastic. It swells in and really touches with a sense of exploration and wonder; and at other times knows to be quiet and allow the natural ambience to do the work. The second-to-last track just before you summit, with its sense of anticipation and adventure, was my favourite.

- Vertical freedom: from climbing Zelda-style (climb higher as you find more Golden Feathers), to the satisfying gliding once you reach the top, very few games have this sense of vertical exploration.

- Ending: without spoilers, I found the ending to be kind of sweet. As they say: A good journey deserves a solid landing, and this one lands quite nicely.

Cons:

- One save file. The inability to have two separate journeys seems like a limiting choice. It's a short game (my first playthrough was 87 minutes, including a few side quests), so it‚Äôs not a huge deal, but still I would‚Äôve preferred multiple save files.

- My biggest gripe: the dialogue. Here are some quotes (slightly paraphrased from memory):
 ‚ÄúJust jammin‚Äô‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like, uh, epic stuff man‚Äù ‚ÄùWelp!‚Äù ‚ÄúHashtag worst dad‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre so basic!‚Äù
 Did I suddenly go hiking surrounded by my millennial tech coworkers from Slack? Cause it seriously detracted from my experience. I know the developer didn't intend it, but I couldn't help but read a layer of irony and insincerity to a lot of the interaction. It would've been fine if a few characters talked like that, but the majority do. Also, the MC says ‚Äú...uh‚Äù way too often. It felt like "A Short Hike" was trying to be relatable, but also self-aware and slightly ironic in that 2010s internet forum way. That‚Äôs not what I expected from a game about hiking and reconnecting with family and nature. As someone who values writing and dialogue very highly, this lost "A Short Hike" a solid 1 point in my books.

Conclusion: It‚Äôs a great short game which doesn‚Äôt overstay it's welcome. It gives a few solid hours of wholesome adventure, and then leaves on a good note. I actually would love more 5‚Äì10 hr well-crafted indies like this, in-between the 40‚Äì80 hour AAA marathons.

Overall score: 7.5 / 10

This is not escapism. This is returning home.

What a beautiful little experience.
Right off the bat, the premise is simple, and it works. You're told to reach the top of Hawk Peak. No timers. No pressure. Just... hike. "A Short Hike", if you will.
But what that premise doesn't prepare you for is just how much the game ends up saying without ever really saying anything (if that makes sense).

Let‚Äôs start with the mechanics, because good god‚Äîthe gliding. It's phenomenal. Freeing, fluid, meditative as hell. You‚Äôre gently riding the wind, barely flapping, just letting it carry you wherever, and I'm totally fine with that.
Climbing‚Äôs just as delightful, though in short bursts, which is a shame, because I adore climbing in games, and I would‚Äôve happily spent half this game just scaling cliffs. But it‚Äôs all wrapped in the golden feather system, which is such a clever little design trick. Your stamina bar is now something tangible. Something you find. It‚Äôs organic and playful, never shoved in your face like, ‚ÄúHey! This is the video game part!‚Äù It just fits, like everything else.

Then you‚Äôve got all the little extras‚Äîfishing (which is super chill), a couple of races, some fetch quests, beachstickball (yes, it‚Äôs a thing), and just... a bunch of tiny things that somehow feel really alive. It never feels like the world exists for you. It feels like things are happening regardless, like you‚Äôre just stepping into a living, breathing place. People are out living their lives, the writing sells that perfectly. Nobody‚Äôs giving you lore dumps or rehearsed speeches, they just talk like folks who got caught mid-task. Short conversations, awkward pauses, sometimes even a little mundane in the best way. It makes the island feel like an actual place, y'know?

And visually? I mean, holy hell. The artstyle floored me. That chunky, pixelated 3D look‚Äîsomewhere between a DS and a GameCube‚Äîis unlike anything I‚Äôve seen. Not in a "ooh, retro" kind of way. It's stylized with purpose. Every tree, every rock, every craggy little trail looks like someone had a good time making it. It‚Äôs cozy, vibrant, weirdly nostalgic. If summer was a video game, this‚Äôd be it. It reminded me of life before everything went to shit‚Äîwhen people went outside just to exist for a while, that's the vibe I get from this place.

And the MUSIC! Don‚Äôt even get me started. Mark Sparling‚Äôs soundtrack is just magic. It‚Äôs calm, whimsical, deeply emotional at times, and always hits at exactly the right moment. There's that scene when you reach the summit, where you're presented with one thing... total silence. Just bloody wind. Then you catch the updraft, and the music slowly swells around you as you take flight. The sky shifts from deep-space purples to fiery oranges, then icy blues, and finally the bright, crisp blue of a summer morning as you reach the ground. It‚Äôs practically fucking poetic.

In addition to that, the open world itself is perfectly scaled, and if I could put it simply, small enough to feel intimate, large enough to make exploration feel rewarding. There‚Äôs no giant objective looming over you, just a gentle encouragement to look around, poke at things, talk to people, climb whatever catches your eye. The game rewards curiosity without ever punishing you for missing something. There‚Äôs always something off the beaten path, and the fact that there‚Äôs no map just makes you trust your instincts more.

The whole thing feels like more than just a cozy indie about birds and mountains. The hike up is the struggle. The glide down is the release. It‚Äôs about letting go, decompressing, learning to slow down and breathe a bit. And it never says that directly, which kinda works in its favor, as it inadvertently creates the space for you to figure it out yourself.

It gave me the same feeling I had when I first played Breath of the Wild, and that‚Äôs not something I say lightly. That quiet wonder. That urge to see what‚Äôs around the next corner, out of pure want, a fiery urge and passion to keep going. Bouncing from peak-to-peak, savoring those moments at the top.
Except here, there‚Äôs only one peak. One big, meaningful climb. And I took my time. I soaked in every minute... and absolutely loved it dammit!!

Needless to say, recommended!

[h2]The go-to game to overcome burnout[/h2]

A Short Hike is a game that captivated me in the first 5 minutes of playtime. Exploring the world feels intuitive and the developers have made every right decision in exploration. The introduction of mechanics is laid out in a way that doesn't force the player on a certain path, but guides them as time goes on. For example, I dove off the starting area in the complete opposite direction out of curiosity and despite that, nothing was wrong - I was even rewarded for it.

It's rare to see a game that does open-ended storytelling justice, you're allowed to do whatever you want and take your time with the things you find interesting. Moving through the world and learning about the environment, people, and even yourself feels like a breath of fresh air. There's no end of the world, no big bad evil to slay; it's just you and the island.

There were a lot of moments where the conversations you had felt like metaphors to real life. I especially enjoyed the first encounter with the fisher, who reassured you that sometimes you have to be patient, and that things will come when the time is right.

I warmly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the simple moments in life, feels a bit lost, or simply doesn't know which game to play next in their library.

THE prime example of the evocative emotional potential videogames can have. 

Perfectly designed world to encourage exploration. Each section of your journey is marked by a campfire and a friendly NPC to lift your spirits. Beautifully conveys what it is to be human. 

THE cozy game of all time.

A Short Hike puts you in the feathers of Claire, a small bird on a small island with one simple goal: climb to the top of a mountain to get cell reception. What follows is less about the destination and more about everything you discover along the way. Fishing, racing, treasure hunting, skipping stones, helping strangers, or just gliding through the air for the sheer joy of it ‚Äî the island is packed with cozy distractions.

The controls are buttery smooth. Climbing feels natural, gliding is pure freedom, and every golden feather you collect expands what you can do. By the end of the hike you are chaining jumps, soaring across valleys, and pretending you are in an extreme sports movie sponsored by birds.

The island itself is delightful to explore. Every path leads somewhere interesting, and wandering off the trail is encouraged. You might find a hidden beach, a secret cave, or an NPC with a surprisingly witty line. The characters you meet are quirky, funny, and often heartwarming, and the small favors you do for them feel meaningful rather than like chores.

Visually, the game uses a charming low-poly style with just enough detail to make the world feel alive. The colors are warm and inviting, and paired with the relaxed soundtrack, the game becomes an instant stress reliever. It is the kind of place you wish you could visit on a real vacation, preferably without worrying about running out of golden feathers halfway up a cliff.

The story is short, but it is told with sincerity and humor. By the time you reach the top of the mountain, the emotional payoff lands perfectly. It is a reminder that sometimes slowing down and enjoying the little things is more rewarding than rushing to the finish line.

Final verdict: A Short Hike is equal parts wholesome adventure, relaxing exploration, and gliding simulator. It is funny, heartfelt, and surprisingly deep for such a compact experience. If you have ever wanted to turn off your brain, breathe in some pixelated mountain air, and race a rabbit while dressed as a bird, this is your game.

A Short Hike is an open world cozy birb simulator developed by adamgryu, also known as Canadian game developer Adam Robinson-Yu by his full name. The original development started as a small break from Untitled Paper RPG, a large scale project that Adam was developing as a sort of spiritual successor to the Paper Mario franchise, a 2D turn based combat RPG known for its beautiful color palette and turn based combat. Development started in 2018 for the game, inspired by shorter indie games and the success that they‚Äôve gathered over the years, and would eventually release a sort of inside look (link below) on Twitter that same month on what he was working on. Eventually after years of hard work and dedication, the game would release to great fanfare and would even have a couple of mods dedicated to it like a Multiplayer Demo that would only be around for two weeks (RIP, wish it was peer to peer officially) and a sort of Google Translate mod which goofs up the dialogue and was inspired by similar Dark Souls mods. He‚Äôd also release the demo for Untitled Paper RPG later on with the caveat that he might never release it in full as well as some sort of Pumpkin Puzzle game for his fans for a limited time. While I‚Äôm very much interested in seeing what this Untitled Paper RPG would look like in the distant future (if it ever happens, such is the curse of indie game design), I wanna bring it back a bit and discuss how I even heard of this game and why I played it. I‚Äôm personally not usually a ‚Äúcozy game‚Äù guy, but I have a lot of respect for the vibes and as such when I heard about this game through my home E‚Äôs DarkRaptor and Bad Ghosts (who has a video on it, check it below), I figured I‚Äôd give it a wishlist. Of course the dork Ghosts would send me the game too and I promised to play it at some point and as such, here we are so here‚Äôs my summary I guess.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AxkCn-8CuwQ&ab_channel=BadGhosts (Ghosts video)

The plot for A Short Hike is a relatively simple one: you play as a young bird named Claire who is dropped off on a ferry headed for Hawk Peak Park to visit her Aunt May for the summer, who works as a ranger there. Claire seems kind of melancholic however, not her usual self and it‚Äôs because it turns out she‚Äôs waiting for a call about ‚Äúthe thing‚Äù. Her Aunt May however tells her that the only phone reception on the entire island is on the top of Hawk Peak and in order to get there you‚Äôll need to go on a ‚Äúshort hike‚Äù, and from there you‚Äôre basically let loose to explore. The actual gameplay itself from here is also rather simple: you basically run around with the goal to collect Golden Feathers; which allow you the ability to climb, fly and jump around for a lot longer. You can get these through finding them in the environment as well as purchasing them (through finding chests full of money, digging up treasure and completing side quests). A lot of these side quests are more on the cozy side and involve racing around the island with certain limits (like using only a certain amount of feathers), playing ‚Äúbeachstickball‚Äù (volleyball but smacking them with sticks) and just talking with fellow islanders. You can navigate around the areas through pouring buckets of water on flower seeds to get a bouncy boost, using hot springs to fight off the cold (which slowly makes you lose your feathers until you sit by a fire/in a hot spring) or gliding and diving around the map. Honestly it‚Äôs a relatively simple loop but it has a decent amount of depth and is honestly just pretty relaxing; this game is a really cozy and chill time that you can legitimately destress to after an awful day and as such I don‚Äôt really have any complaints about it. It‚Äôs just fun, maybe not fun in the traditional sense for me in the sense of shooting gangsters on the street (in a video game), but a nice time where you can just zone out and decompress. Also to finish the story section (spoilers ahead), [spoiler]the plot finishes when Claire reaches the top of Hawk Peak and calls her Mom who reveals what the worries have been about: she‚Äôs had surgery which goes fine. Eventually they talk about how her mother and Aunt May used to hike up there all the time and honestly get into a heartwarming talk about being worried for each other and communication before Mom tells her to ‚Äúcatch the drift‚Äù. Doing so allows you to capture Hawk Peak‚Äôs majestic atmosphere on the way down and talking to Aunt May will have you recount your adventures before you go to sleep.[/spoiler]

To summarize my feelings on atmosphere and sound design, I‚Äôm just going to state here first that there‚Äôs no voice acting and honestly that‚Äôs fine because the game doesn‚Äôt really need it anyhow. In a lot of ways it‚Äôs very similar to Animal Crossing, where you hear repetitive sound pitched noises as their way of communicating and Animal Crossing is pretty cool so no complaints. The game itself is beautiful as hell, filled with vibrant colors directly inspired by ‚ÄúThe Canadian Shield‚Äù in Autumn, an area for which I‚Äôve never been to but can imagine being cold as hell. If this is what the game looks like, then perhaps one day it would be cool to go up there because honestly the game is beautiful. Also I‚Äôm a sucker for the Playstation One styled ‚Äúchunky graphic‚Äù style, having a fondness for indie horror games developed by the likes of Torture Star so this is also all very appealing. The actual sound design itself is great too, and sounds immersive as you splash amongst the rivers near the beaches or the pattering of the climbs up the cold stone wall to the peak of the mountain.  Finally there‚Äôs the soundtrack: composed by Mark Sparling, it was inspired by soundtracks for older games like Firewatch and Animal Crossing: New Leaf (which he listened to every day while creating the compositions) among other artists like Studio Ghibli‚Äôs Joe Hasashi and kind of emulating that wholesome uplifting style lo-fi style that really hits the vibes well. I don‚Äôt know if I could really list a ‚Äúfavorite track‚Äù persay though I‚Äôd probably list ‚ÄúSnow, Lots of Snow‚Äù for it‚Äôs calmer and somber sounding piano/string combinations. Either way to be honest, everything pretty much fits as you‚Äôd expect for a super wholesome and positive feeling cozy game. Honestly that‚Äôs pretty much how I would summarize my feelings on the game as well: it's a positive feeling, super wholesome and just a nice time and honestly in the f u c k ed up world that we live in and all the s h i t t y feelings that inhabit it? It‚Äôs a nice break to take after dealing with all of that, and if I were to give a general runtime I would say it depends on how long you wanna stay. I spent around three and a half hours completing the game and exploring it but my dude Ghosts spent at least twelve hours just kind of exploring and vibing on his own so just take it at your own pace and enjoy it, especially considering it‚Äôs only eight dollars at most not on sale?

Other than that A Short Hike is a great game and it's pretty good for relaxing and discovering new places. Praising this game is like beating a dead horse, but I will say this game is still a lot of fun. Granted, I also feel this game is a bit overpriced when at its full-price (though $8 is not asking for that much anyway). The game is very short, as the name suggests, probably clocking around 2 to 3 hours to get a majority of the quests done, on top of exploring the island to its fullest. Even getting all of the achievements really doesn't take very long either (though I needed a guide, especially for the fishing). 

Regardless, this is such a nice shortform game. From the plethora of movement options with running, flying, climbing, and even getting a boat(!!), the game has the spirit of Animal Crossing with the freeform exploration of Breath of the Wild. The movement is incredibly satisfying, especially when you pick up a ton of air and you learn how to dive to pick up speed. Oh yeah, that's real nice. The game's challenges are enjoyable, but borderline become jokes once you collect all of the feathers. But the progression is steady and probably after an hour you'll probably be at the very peak Claire was told about at the beginning of the game. The island has plenty of little secrets hidden within and without, with some extra little islands that may be a bit more hidden(!) There's fishing, treasure hunting, races, hidden paths, characters, collectibles, etc. Why yes, this game is quite cozy! The island is peppered with abundant foliage and biomes - all encompassed on this small, mountainous island. The characters are warm and welcoming, with some showing their own vulnerabilities and growth even in the short runtime. And the music is also quite nice, with some accordions, acoustic guitars, synths, chiptunes, pianos, and so on, with a dynamic sheen where instruments, sections, and even full on songs transitioning in and out depending on what part of the island you're on or how fast you may be moving. Once again, feels like a mashup of Animal Crossing and Breath of the Wild's compositions and designs. 

I'd rank this game higher if, again, it wasn't for the fact it was just, so short! I know that was its purpose, but this isn't a game i'll probably be coming back to, not anytime soon at least. However, I also finished this in three separate play sessions. Depending on the person you are, that's not exactly a bad thing - sometimes games don't need to be played for hundreds of hours to be good - honestly I feel most of bethesda's catalogue is proof having a game that is hundreds of hours long doesn't make it fun or enjoyable. 

Still, this game just doesn't have that much replay value compared to other 3D platformers or even other "cozy" games in the same vein. Considering how popular this game was, it certainly had a lasting impact and inspired its own throe of cozy 3D collect-a-thons too. The amount of things the game does is still very impressive in its own right, I just feel the game's enjoyment factor is capped by its length for me.

The goal is simple - go up the mountain - but the game still had me feeling like I was in an open world. I liked how I could decide for myself how focused or branched-out I wanted to play, and that there was something simple and fun to do, no matter what path I chose. The controls have the best parts of simple isometric gamepad adventure movement, and on top of the that some nicely done flying, gliding and climbing. It's quite short, but it managed to feel longer because of packed it was with daring jumps, NPC interaction, exploration and quest fulfillment. Very good!

I could probably write a fair amount of why this game is so appealing. The biggest reason, I contend, is that this game is one the most "chill" games you'll play. 'Chill' meaning: Low stakes and low difficulty, with a cozy aesthetic, and an emphasis on slow exploration. This game captures the feeling of reading a good book on a beach vacation. An idle delight that passes the day, while you occasionally stop to enjoy the view.

Short and memorable, it's easy to see why it's so universally praised.

This game is... uh... short, but the exploration is very fun, cute, and the art style only grows on you as you go. A Short Hike is a wonderful game of exploring and enjoying the scenery. Very Fun and relaxing game. I played this game as a break from larger games and it made me appreciate gaming much more. Highly recommend on sales.

A Short Hike is a cozy platformer where you hike to the top of a mountain. The movement in this game is really fun, flying around is a blast, and collecting more feathers so you can fly higher/further always feels worth it. The art style in this game is really interesting, the game defaults to a very pixelated art style but you can turn that down/off. I see the charm in the pixelated version but I do prefer to have it off. The characters around the mountain have some funny dialogue and the challenges they provide are fun additions to the game. This game does a good job at not overstaying its welcome, taking only about 4 hours to 100%. Overall, A Short Hike is a fun platformer with a lot of charm and is the perfect length to keep you wanting just a little bit more.

A charming little exploration game that is relaxing both in its atmosphere and its game design. There are activities to do, but you're not forced into anything. If you need to relax, play this.
